references: Lackey, J. A. 1991. Chaetodipus spinatus. Am. Soc. Mamm., Mammalian species No. 385:1-4.
Miller, A.H. and R.C. Stebbins. 1964. The lives of desert animals in Joshua Tree National Monument. University of California Press, Berkeley and Los Angeles.
Zeiner, D. C., et al., editors. 1990. California's wildlife. Vol. II. Mammals. California Dept. Fish & Game, Sacramento. xi + 407 pp.
Grinnell, J. 1933. Review of the recent mammal fauna of California. Univ. Calif. Publ. Zool. 40:71-234.
Ryser, F.A. 1964. Spiny pocket mouse in Nevada. Journal of Mammalogy, 45:301-302.
habitat_description:
Southwest:
There is virtually no information concerning habitat requirements of this species. In Clark County, Nevada, this species was trapped at seepage areas or close to tamarisk or mesquite trees in the southern portion of the state at Granite Springs (Ryser 1964). This species usually occurs within rocky and sloping topography (Lackey 1991).  In the United States, it occurs from southern Nevada southward in a narrow strip to the U.S.-Mexico boundary (Lackey 1991).
In California, "two forms occur, C. s. rufescens occurs in rough terrain and narrow washes
in hillls south from Palm Springs to the border of Mexico (Riverside and San Diego cos.). C. s.
spinatus inhabits the southeastern corner of the state on rocky slopes vegetated by desert
scrub (Grinnell 1933), from Needles south along the Colorado River Valley to the border of
Mexico. Few reports of this species can be found. It seems to prefer sparsely covered
desert scrub habitats on stony soils and rocky washes. The elevational range is from 45-900
m (150-3000 ft)." (quoted directly from [Brylski et al. 2007] based on Zeiner et al. 1990). This species is known to dig burrows at the base of desert shrubs along rocky mesas, hillsides, and desert washes.
